stream_context.summary: Kaze primarily worked on the final Bowser boss fight, implementing grab and throw mechanics and debugging Bowser's AI pathing. This led to a major detour to fix long-standing bugs with how held objects are rendered, using the Resnor boss as a test case. He also integrated new tutorial sign models from Biobak and fixed background element pop-in on the Bowser level.

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented a major optimization to the floor collision system that fixes the 'floor cocking' bug by selectively culling surfaces and only loading essential data, improving performance.
development_findings.quote: So since we need to fix floor clacking like this, we originally had to remove the sorting priority as well. But I had the idea, what if we just keep the sorting priority, and we kill all the floors that are too high, and then we can just only iterate 0x10 bytes of each floor?

development_findings.summary: A new, highly optimized sine and cosine function using imaginary numbers has been implemented, which is reportedly twice as fast.
development_findings.quote: just recently we have the most correct sine and cosine function now... we're using imaginary numbers.

development_findings.summary: A new animation format for Mario is being developed by contributor Lilaa. Kaze anticipates it will break many existing things but accepts this as necessary for long-term improvement.
development_findings.quote: Yeah, Mario's going to get a new animation format in that Lilaa's making. And that's going to fuck a lot of shit up here, too. I don't mind just breaking a bunch of stuff. It means the game is going to be better forever.

development_findings.summary: The final version of the game has diverged so significantly from the public demo that it is considered an almost entirely new experience.
development_findings.quote: The actual final game is so unrecognizable from the demo right now it's actually crazy.

development_findings.summary: The project is constrained by the 64MB ROM limit, with streamed music consuming over 70% of the current file size (32.1MB of 44.6MB).
development_findings.quote: Currently, the ROM is 44.6 megabytes and 32.1 megabytes is music because we have a lot of stream to music.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is actively working on the final Bowser boss fight, implementing mechanics for Bowser chasing Mario, being grabbed by the tail, and being thrown off the ship arena.
To save polygons, background ships are only half-modeled. Kaze uses a trick with negative scaling and face culling to render the other side, effectively mirroring the geometry.
development_findings.quote: I have to use a negative scale because the ships are only half modeled so what I do is I use a negative scale and I Turn on front face culling and turn off back face culling. So that way the ship only is like about half the amount of polygons.

development_findings.summary: A bug causing newly spawned objects like tutorial signs to bounce was traced to an issue where their interpolated position was not being set correctly upon creation.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes his work is legal but plans to delay the open-source release for about two months to prevent an immediate Nintendo takedown and to hide Easter eggs.
context_findings.quote: What I'm doing is perfectly legal. Like, they literally cannot ban me from doing this... Yeah, we should probably delay open sourcing the game a little from the initial release, just so Nintendo doesn't instantly take it down.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a strong design philosophy against including many options in games, arguing it leads to player confusion and a less cohesive, shared experience.
context_findings.quote: I hate options. I think games should give you as few options as possible... a bunch of options are just unnecessarily confusing and people aren't going to have all the same experience, which I don't like.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes 'Return to Yoshi's Island' will be much more popular and beloved than his previous major project, 'Last Impact'.
context_findings.quote: I think this one's gonna be different. I think everyone's gonna love this game and that's gonna make its popularity skyrocket.

context_findings.summary: The decision to move streaming from Twitch to YouTube was driven by community feedback and superior financial incentives.
context_findings.quote: I switched from Twitch to YouTube because community polls showed a clear preference, and YouTube offers a better revenue split (70/30 vs. Twitch's 50/50).

context_findings.summary: Kaze prioritizes freedom of movement and skill expression in platformers, which is why he prefers games like Mario 64 and Sonic Adventure over exploration-focused games like Banjo-Kazooie.
context_findings.quote: I'm very picky with games. And for me, Banjo-Kazooie is just kind of boring... For me, what's really important in a platformer is that I get that sense of freedom. That sense of skill expression.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentions that he and Zeina are saving money with the long-term goal of buying a house.
context_findings.quote: I gotta save up so we can eventually get a house.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is a professional Unreal Engine developer, a career he finds more lucrative than ROM hacking, and would use it for any original commercial game.
context_findings.quote: if I'm making my own game, I'm just gonna use Unreal Engine. I'm actually a professional developer in Unreal Engine already. I get paid a lot for that.

biobak.summary: Biobak created and sent Kaze the 3D models for the tutorial bunnies' text boxes, which Kaze then implemented and debugged during the stream.

zeina.summary: Zeina's official role on the project is handling animations and artwork.
zeina.quote: Zaina's job here is animations and artwork.

zeina.summary: Kaze jokingly calls Zeina his 'animation slave', and she clarifies that she enjoys the work and finds it to be good practice and portfolio-building.
zeina.quote: My animation slave in the background... I mean, animations are fun for me.

zeina.summary: Outside of the project, Zeina works as a kitchen cook, a job she generally dislikes but finds tolerable due to her current team.
zeina.quote: I am currently a kitchen cook and I hate kitchens. I hate it. Actually, that's not entirely true. I have a good team to work with right now.

key_stories.title: Fixing the 'Floor Cocking' Bug
key_stories.summary: Kaze devised a significant optimization for the game's collision detection. He solved a long-standing engine bug called 'floor cocking' not by removing the problematic code, but by cleverly refining it to filter out irrelevant data, resulting in a more stable and performant game.
key_stories.challenge: The original Mario 64 engine has a bug known as 'floor cocking,' where one surface can incorrectly hide another, causing the player to fall through the world. A naive fix is inefficient.
key_stories.process: Instead of removing the engine's surface sorting, Kaze kept it but added a check to discard any floors that were too high to be relevant. He then further optimized it by having the function only load the Y-coordinate data (the first 16 bytes) of the remaining surfaces into the cache, significantly reducing data processing.
key_stories.outcome: The new method fixes the bug while being highly optimal, as it avoids iterating through unnecessary data for distant or irrelevant floor polygons.
key_stories.key_quote: I had the idea, what if we just keep the sorting priority, and we kill all the floors that are too high, and then we can just only iterate 0x10 bytes of each floor?

key_stories.title: The Held Object Rotation Bug
key_stories.summary: A complex bug caused objects held by Mario to rotate and position themselves incorrectly. Kaze undertook a lengthy live debugging session, isolating the faulty code piece by piece until he could rewrite the logic for how object transformations are handled, fixing the bug for multiple bosses.
key_stories.challenge: When Mario grabbed an object, specifically the Resnor boss, its position and rotation were completely wrong, and it animated at 30 FPS instead of 60.
key_stories.process: Kaze systematically debugged the issue by removing code blocks to isolate the problem. He discovered the error was in the complex interaction between Mario's state, the held object's properties, and the order in which rotation and position data were being applied. He had to refactor the code to ensure the angles were copied correctly before the object's position was offset.
key_stories.outcome: After extensive debugging, Kaze fixed the code that copies the angle and position data to the held object, resolving the visual glitches and ensuring it animates smoothly. This fix is also crucial for the Bowser fight.
key_stories.key_quote: The crazy part is that they seem to completely ignore what Mario is doing. Like entirely.

key_stories.title: The Bouncing Tutorial Signs
key_stories.summary: When implementing new models from Biobak, Kaze encountered a strange bug where the static objects would bounce. He deduced it was a frame rate-dependent issue caused by using the wrong spawning function, which failed to properly initialize the object's position, and fixed it by using the correct function.
key_stories.challenge: New 3D models for tutorial signs, provided by Biobak, were inexplicably bouncing up and down when loaded into the game.
key_stories.process: Kaze noticed the bug was tied to the frame rate. He theorized it was caused by a function that sets an object's position every frame. He realized the function he used to spawn the signs was intended for dynamic objects and didn't correctly initialize the interpolated position, causing a feedback loop. He moved the sign spawning to a different function to resolve it.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully fixed the bug, and the tutorial signs now appear static as intended. The fix involved ensuring the object's interpolated position was set correctly upon spawning.
key_stories.key_quote: This coincides with the frame rate, doesn't it? Yellow got 30 FPS, it doesn't happen. What? I have a theory.
